clinical_study.brief_title: Comparative Bioavailability Study of Film-coated Tablet and Granule Formulations of RG1662
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Open-Label, Four Period, Four-Treatment Crossover Study to Investigate the Comparative Bioavailability of Film-Coated Tablet and Granule Formulations of RG1662 Under Fed and Fasted Conditions in Healthy Volunteers

brief_summary.textblock: This study will compare the pharmacokinetic performance of film-coated tablet and granule formulations of RG1662 under fed and fasted conditions in healthy volunteers. A randomized, four-period, four-treatment crossover design is used. In each period, each volunteer will receive a single oral dose of the tablet or granule formulation either with or without food.

primary_outcome.measure: Granules Fed (test): RG1662 plasma exposure, area under the concentration-time curve
Granules Fasted (test): RG1662 plasma exposure, area under the concentration-time curve
Tablet Fed (reference): RG1662 plasma exposure, area under the concentration-time curve
Tablet Fasted (reference): RG1662 plasma exposure, area under the concentration-time curve

secondary_outcome.measure: Tablet formulation: RG1662 plasma exposure ratio between fed (test) and fasted (reference) conditions, estimated from area under the concentration-time curve measurements
Granule formulation: RG1662 plasma exposure ratio between fed (test) and fasted (reference) conditions, estimated from area under the concentration-time curve measurements
Palatability of the granule formulation, as assessed by questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1, Day 3 in granule administration periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety: Incidence of adverse events with either formulation

intervention.description: Single dose, oral administration of RG1662 immediate release granules
Single dose, oral administration of film-coated RG1662 immediate release tablet

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female volunteers, 18 to 60 years of age, inclusive
Exclusion Criteria:
- A history of epilepsy, convulsions or significant head injury
- Any other clinically relevant abnormalities, concomitant diseases or ongoing medical conditions
